Though, seriously, quantum mechanics aside, I have found that, when I am dithering on a choice, if I flip a coin, and then check my own emotional reaction to see if I'm disappointed or not, I can resolve the decision. If I am not disappointed, I go with what the coin flip said. If I am disappointed, I go with the other option. (This may not actually preclude that I would've been disappointed either way, but IF that's the case, it's just like if I would've been happy either way: the coin flip still made a decision, and I know that by going the other way if I was disappointed, I at least am avoiding one choice that would have disappointed me.)

Great video, but some subtle problem is that the protocol given seems to have a problem; in fact, in this scenario it is possible for Jade to 'cheat' if she doesn't actually measure all of the qubits as they come in, and instead stores them to read them later using a more complicated multi-particle measurement during the verification step (even if photons themselves can't be stored easily, can trigger a CNOT with some other storable qubit). Really, the weakness lies in the inability to force Jade to make intermediate measurements (which seems to be impossible without some form of bit-commitment or oblivious transfer, which is proven to be impossible without standard cryptographic assumptions). Additionally, if you had bit-commitment it's possible for each party to just commit a single bit, and then xor both of them after both bits are committed so they can't change. It turns out that perfect coin flips are impossible without a certain amount of bias (kitaev's coin flipping bound see https://cs.uwaterloo.ca/~watrous/CS867.Winter2017/Notes/08.pdf, would love to see a video on it :) ), but you can guarantee a quantum coin flip to be biased by at most 1/sqrt(2) - 1/2 ≈ 20% (classically, this is impossible).

There is an admittedly rare and minor fail condition.  Since each bit can be measured exactly once, there is a chance that the random bits match the missing bits from the correct polarizer, both columns match, and you have to do it over.  So, two questions:  What is the random chance of a match on both sides, based on the number of bits?  And:  Can you arrange the bits, or limit the set of usable binary numbers, to ensure this chance does not happen?

Is there an error in this video 5:35? She says that, if person A had been cheating and had in fact used diagonal filters, person A could prove her innocence by reading off the "diagonal" column. But the diagonal column of the person B will not match that of person B, because person B will may wrongly record vertical photons (coded by person A as 1s) to be 0s if they don't pass through -- assuming we're using the 1-valued diagonal filter -- or to be 0s if they do pass through -- assuming we're using the 0-valued diagonal filter. So there's no way person A could confidently match person B's data based on her own.


Presumably, then, person A can only read off the rectilinear column as a kind of proof. Which works if person B guesses diagonal and wants to know they weren't duped; person A would clearly only know the rectilinear data if they had knew the state of all the photons themselves. But consider the opposite case: person B guesses rectilinear when person A used diagonal and wants to know she hasn't been duped. Person A can't -- with certainty -- read off person B's diagonal filter because of the probablistic nature of diagonal polarization. (And person A clearly can't simply proclaim that they don't know the rectilinear sequence; that implies person A is trustworthy, which is the very assumption we're designed this experiment to eliminate.) So Person B can't be reassured by a correspondence of binary subsequences, and we again destabilize into distrust.

I thought of another solution to the same problem

You both flip a coin.
Let's choose that if both coins have the same side Dianne wins, and if they have different faces Jade wins. (50% probability of each)
Then create a spare email ID. The password to which is known to only one of them, let's say Dianne, as she creates it.
Dianne then mails her result on that email id and tells Jade that she has done so.
Then after that Jade sends her result and the password of that email id is made public to both of them.
And they see the answer.
Dianne couldn't have cheated by waiting to see Jade's result as the time at which an email is sent is also visible.

Wait. you aren't measuring light by passing it through a diagonal filter - you are filtering it. There's a huge difference. Regardless of whether you cause a change in the wave form or not, you didn't do it by measuring it, you did it by filtering it. If you were actually measuring it, you'd be finding out how much light was passing a given point during a given time. And THAT would not cause any changes.

Here's a non-quantum cryptographic way to flip a coin, in case anyone's interested:

Diana randomly generates two large prime numbers which are either both 1 mod 4, or both 3 mod 4. She multiplies them together and tells Jade the result. Jade then has to guess whether the primes are both 1 mod 4 or both 3 mod 4; she has a 50% chance of being right, and if she's wrong, Diana can prove it by revealing the primes.

Can I get some clarification on how this system can't be hacked or faked?
1. Alice sends a string of bits to Bob. She knows that string of bits and can just repeat it during verification.
2. Bob could use just 1 filter and never change it. For example, just one diagonal. Bob will get a string that is either the same as the bits sent, random, or opposite of the bits sent (1s and 0s swapped). If the result is the same or opposite that of the bits sent, he used the correct polarization.

Dianna, I have a question about the polarized filters, specifically in regards to radio waves. I work in the telecommunications field, so this questions is actually pretty intriguing to me. Since light and radio waves are both EM waves, how would, say, a 10Ghz microwave (used for backhaul in cell networks) be affected by these filters? Would the signal survive passing through the three filters, and would the modulation of the wave be intact enough to still maintain signal reception? Would the signal be distorted to the point of being useless?

This is impractical

You can use every arbitrary coin (no matter how unbalanced) for a perfectly fair coin toss: Instead of using head or tails as the results, use head-tail and tail-head as results (so you toss the coin twice). If it's head-head or tail-tail, you repeat the process. I know it doesn't have anything to do with the actual topic of the video, but it's still a perfect coin toss.

You could also use entangled particles as coins - the moment you look at it, collapse happens and the other person with their particle is in the opposite state to what you see with your particle. But the result itself is random.

There is a big error in this explain; Photons do not get blocked. They get different properties.
See a photon as a pixel with alpha channel.
If the color is white, 100%. It's visibility is 100%.
If it's white and 50%, photon's go through 50% of the time, aka 1 photon does and 1 not.
This is what you're affecting with the filters, the visibility of a photon.

This is not how quantum physics works sadly your polarizers are interacting with the light effectively changing its state so the experiment is invalid: heres an explanation of what is realy happening http://alienryderflex.com/polarizer/

Partial spins is why they make it thru.  a photon at a spin of 0, vertical, will pass thru the horizontal and not vertical.  as will a spin of 12, 18, 22, 30 degrees.  The same applies to the photons at a spin of 90 will pass thru the vertical, but not the horizontal, as will a spin of 67, 80, 83, degrees.  The reason the 45 degree filter works is the duality of wave particle properties.  The filters do change the outcome, as indicated by Schrodinger, in a manner to cause the lower wave/spin 45 degree  photons to be present to pass thru the horizontal filter.

Nowadays, if the two sides can agree who gets the choice based on a single bit, a way to get a random (albeit public once found) bit for both sides is to wait for the next Bitcoin block (about once every 10 minutes) and take the last bit of the block hash. Because the Bitcoin network is so big nowadays, it would be prohibitively expensive to influence the hash of the next block to any measurable degree.

Actually, this is an inaccurate explanation, it requires a quantum explanation since you can do this with a single photon. The polarization doesn't actually change, just the that the new angle no longer includes the directions that were blocked out by the filter. What the middle layer actually does it cause the quantum system to go back into its "unknown" state as if it never went through the first filter at all (Yes it goes back in time). The first filter is collapsing the wave function, which is why only some of the light gets through, the middle filter effectively scrambles the information back into a wave probability and what happened at the first filter is no longer relevant (it erases it's previous knowledge of ever going through the first filter). Look up the quantum eraser experiment, it's effectively the exact same thing. Also, here's Veritasium: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zcqZHYo7ONs
Quantum eraser: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8ORLN_KwAgs

This is not the same as a coin toss; it is more like rock, paper, scissors. The reason it's different is because there is a person choosing it, and possibly a person you know well, and who knows you well. So, in addition to the element of uncertainty, there is also some psychology involved, especially if you play this game a lot. So for example, you may know that your friend favors diagonal filter when guessing, so you will be better off picking rectilinear. The same way that someone can be good or bad at RPS, someone could be good or bad at this "coin flip", which defeats the purpose of a coin flip.

This should tell you why it's possible to capture an image with a device otherwise designed to display one (lcd screen/etc). That's right, cameras are not necessary, just different circuitry passed through the same device in another way. The moral of the story is, putting a sticker over your "camera" is not going to prevent the feds (or anyone else who knows how) from getting an image of you doing "whatever". Sorry.

One of my favourite ways to do this is where both parties flip a coin, then after a countown, they simultaneously announce to the other what they got.

The cool thing is that there is a 50% chance that both parties get the same result, and a 50% chance that one gets heads and the other gets tails. So decide beforehand which concert that "different" will give you, and which concert that "same" will give you.

Does this have anything to do with the double slit experiment? It sounds similar...

So, when talking about 45° angles relative to light passing through, you state that half of the light is blocked and half of the light passes through, which is correct on a macro scale. But my question is whether that is true on the scale of the photon with which you're portraying it. Are you actually stopping one photon that is 45° offset and then allowing one through, as described. Or is the crystal lattice of the polarizing film absorbing the energy of the light proportionally to the relative angle? The best way of thinking of it that I have been told is that each photon makes it through the filter, but it has the horizontal component of it energy absorbed by the polarizing film. Such that when its 0° offset it passes fully through, at a 45° the horizontal component is equivalent to 1/2 its energy is absorbed, and at 90° the horizontal component is the full energy of the light, and thus is fully absorbed.
This is a very interesting topic to me, and I think that its something that is often misunderstood or portrayed poorly, because its very difficult to explain to people.
